newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIAN RUPEE ENDS DOWN AS SBI DLR DEMAND EMERGES.
newsitem.headline: INDIAN RUPEE ENDS DOWN AS SBI DLR DEMAND EMERGES.

text.p: The rupee weakened mildly against the dollar to close at 35.7250/7300 as demand from India's largest bank State Bank of India (SBI) re-emerged on Wednesday from near oblivion, dealers said.
The spot rupee opened the day steady at 35.715/720 a dollar.
"They (SBI) were buying dollars throughout the day, bidding from 35.7150 upto 35.7350," a dealer at a foreign bank said.
"They bought close to $100 million today," another dealer said. "There was hardly any demand from anyone else."
A leading term-lending bank and a leading Ahmedabad-based textile major were selling dollars on Wednesday, dealers said.

SBI, whose demand usually moves the forex market, was in the background in recent months, and the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has been at centre-stage, buying dollars to arrest the rupee's rise against dollars, dealers said.
Some dealers said SBI was buying for the state-run Oil and Natural Gas Corp among others, but neither SBI or ONGC officials were immediately available for confirmation.
Forward premiums opened lower but edged up during the day.
"Far-forward premiums were little changed but near term premiums ended some two paise lower," said a dealer.
December maturity dollars saw some activity but the forward market was largely dull during the day, dealers said.
The six-month annualised forward premium closed Wednesday at 4.53 percent, almost unchanged from the previous 4.54 percent.

"Permission to foreign institutional investors (FIIs) to take forward cover on their debt investments is the right way but not enough to cause a strong move (in the exchange rate)," a European bank said in its India commentary on Wednesday.
"Anyway it seems we will celebrate India's 50th birthday with a strong rupee!" it said.
The 50th anniversary of India's independence falls on August 15 -- a national holiday -- at a time when the Indian currency is one of the few that has stayed strong against the dollar.
